text.tspan: Kumar
Kyle Kumar
Neil Johnson
Writing 2
December 9, 2021
From Academic Article to Brief Advertisement
My genre translation takes the academic article “Distracted Biking: An Observational
Study,” and converts it into the solution that the article proposes. The original article argues that
distracted biking is a rampant problem that could be addressed with education campaigns and
legislative reform (Wolfe 2016). Consequently, my project is an advertisement for a legal
proposition that teaches students the dangers of distracted biking while enforcing stricter
punishments for those who put themselves and others in danger.
I worked to match the genre expectations of an advertisement. According to Elizabeth
Wardle and Doug Downs in
Writing About Writing
, “genres
emerge because writers start to find
ways to respond to the recur-ring situation that seem to work pretty well,” and in terms of the
genre of advertisements, what works well is being brief but leaving an impact (Downs 2020).
Oftentimes, advertisements have to pay for space and time, so once a reader engages with an
advertisement it is imperative that they do not lose focus until the main idea has been
established. Furthermore, an advertisement needs to leave a lasting impact on readers so that it
has a tangible effect on their future behavior. And, finally, as achieving both of these results
becomes harder as the number of possible viewers increases, an advertisement is often targeted
towards a specific group of people so that it can have a large effect on a few people instead of
having a weak effect on many people.
